results.title: The Acting mayor = Dai li shi zhang
results.creator_credit: Beijing Film Studio and Yang Zaibao
results.brief_description:
The film is about China’s economic reform in the 1980s. Xiao grew up in Thailand and returned to China in the 1960s. Newly appointed as acting mayor of the Yingzhou city, Xiao announced that he would do ten good things for the city at his inauguration. He encouraged the local peasants to build a bridge through self-financing, and he lent his support to the director of Baiyun Pharmaceutical Factory in terms of promoting a blacklisted engineer, Li Huaxin. Xiao also helped Li Huaxin’s daughter, who was not allowed to go abroad to study because of her father’s background. As an acting mayor, Xiao made some achievements but also aroused controversy. Even the Party Secretary, who had been supportive, thought that Xiao was too radical in some aspects. Xiao’s wife and daughter are concerned about people’s misunderstanding, but Xiao is determined to carry on the reforms, believing that he is in line with the central government as long as what he does benefits the people. At a news conference, Xiao says he would rather break rules than go against the will of the people. In order to fulfill his promise to do ten good things, Xiao asks for a new term of three months as acting mayor.

The film should be understood in relation to China’s reform in the early 1980s. It was reported that the film aroused controversy when it was shown to senior officials in the central government. Hardliners in the Communist Party insisted that the film need a few cuts before it could be released for public screening. However, the then Chinese Premier, Hu Yaobang gave green light to the film. The leading actor of the film, Yang Zaibao also starred in The Meeting of Two Heroes. (4 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)

results.title: The Acid house (D)
results.creator_credit: Channel 4 Television, David Muir, Alex Usborne and Paul McGuigan
results.brief_description: Three stories from Irvine Welsh’s first collection have been adapted in this tongue-in-cheek response to “Trainspotting” and the emergence of The Chemical Generation, a movement Welsh helped to spawn. “The Granton Star Cause”, “A Soft Touch” and “The Acid House” are lethal Scottish fables of drugs, booze and all that which is valued above humanity in the depths of post-Thatcher Britain. But they are also comedies, loud with pitch-black laughter that echoes across a bleak urban landscape where God spends his days in the pub and even the most successful search for identity only leads to hooliganism and excrement. Featuring an unusually intelligent pop-soundtrack, “The Acid House” is not a life-affirming comedy, but it is social commentary at its most painfully entertaining.

results.title: The Accused
results.creator_credit: Alley Kat Productions, ScreenWest, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Alan Carter
results.brief_description: A reality program providing an inside look into a criminal trial which took place in Perth. The key players in this real-life drama are: the Accused; Laurie Levy and Philip Dunn QC for the Defence; Hilton Dembo for the Prosecution; Justice Christine Wheeler as the presiding Judge; an observer in the Public Gallery; and the three key witnesses (portrayed by actors). The law prohibits any filming of a jury and there was also a Court Order protecting the three key witnesses. The accused has been charged of importing 13kg of drugs, mainly amphetamines and ecstacy, and if found guilty, could be sentenced to a maximum of 25 years in prison. This is an interesting and entertaining program showing the workings of the court, the day-to-day procedures, the strategies and legal tactics of both the Defence and the Prosecution, the questioning of the witnesses, all interspersed with personal commentaries from some of those involved. Tension, drama, witty exchanges, human frailties are all part of a day’s work for the barristers and lawyers and as such “The Accused” reveals the human side of what is often thought of as an intimidating and rigidly conservative environment. It is worth watching just to experience the tension and build-up of frustration when waiting for the jury’s verdict. Narrated by Tony Martin. NOTE: “This is the first time a full criminal trial has been filmed in Australia.”

results.title: The Accursed architect
results.creator_credit: La Societe Nouvelle Pathe-Cinema and Pierre Cast
results.brief_description: An investigation of the work and theories of Claude-Nicolas Ledoux, 1736-1806, an architect and innovator two centuries before his time. Initially he created chateaux for the French nobility, but later he became an urbanist, designing houses and cities for the working man. However, his utopian dream that architecture should be related to daily life was not realised.

results.title: The Accident
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Carol Carrick. A poignant film about growing up, anger and responsibility, loss and acceptance. Chris’ dog is run over and killed while he is on holiday. Chris becomes angry when his father buries the dog without consulting him. His anger turns to respect when his father takes him to the grave and together they select a special boulder as a grave marker. In the end Chris learns how to cope with tragedy and how accidents can be prevented. The sequel to this story is “The Foundling”.

results.title: The Accessible Arctic
results.brief_description: Convincing evidence of the growing advance of industry and settlement in the Canadian far north. New roads, railways and airfields have brought the once isolated northern communities into the mainstream of Canadian life and progress. Explains how this is being done and shows some of the people who are doing it. Among these are Indian and Eskimo graduates of the new trade schools.

results.title: The Aborigines of Australia
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnall and Ian Dunlop
results.brief_description: Examines the aboriginal and part-aboriginal situation in Australia today (1964), showing some of the problems associated with their welfare and the policies aimed at their assimilation. Surveys conditions on government welfare settlements and mission stations, where different tribes learn to live together, and are taught new social, occupational and educational skills. Many work happily with other Australians in the Northern Australian cattle industry, but in towns stand apart from the rest of the community. Notes how social barriers need to be overcome if assimilation is to take place.

results.title: The Abode of peace
results.creator_credit: Malayan Film Unit, B.H. Hipkins and Ow Kheng Law
results.brief_description: The British Protected Sultanate of Brunei lies on the northern coastline of the island of Borneo, between North Borneo and Sarawak. This film is an account of Brunei’s struggle to preserve the best of an old civilisation while using the new prosperity brought by the discovery of oil in the territory to build roads, schools and hospitals.
